text: Ḍa (also romanized as Dda) is a consonant of Indic abugidas. In modern Indic scripts, Dda is derived from the early "Ashoka" Brahmi letter ng after having gone through the Gupta letter 13px. As with the other cerebral consonants, ḍa is not found in most scripts for Tai, Sino-Tibetan, and other non-Indic languages, except for a few scripts, which retain these letters for transcribing Sanskrit religious terms. ==Āryabhaṭa numeration== Aryabhata used Devanagari letters for numbers, very similar to the Greek numerals, even after the invention of Indian numerals. The values of the different forms of ठ are: *ड = 13 (१३) *डि = 1,300 (१ ३००) *डु = 130,000 (१ ३० ०००) *डृ = 13,000,000 (१ ३० ०० ०००) *डॢ = 1,300,000,000 (१ ३० ०० ०० ०००) *डे = 13 (१३×१०१०) *डै = 13 (१३×१०१२) *डो = 13 (१३×१०१४) *डौ = 13 (१३×१०१६) ==Historic Dda== There are three different general early historic scripts - Brahmi and its variants, Kharoṣṭhī, and Tocharian, the so-called slanting Brahmi. Dda as found in standard Brahmi, Dda was a simple geometric shape, with variations toward more flowing forms by the Gupta Dda. The Tocharian Dda Dda did not have an alterante Fremdzeichen form. The third form of dda, in Kharoshthi (Dda) was probably derived from Aramaic separately from the Brahmi letter. ===Brahmi Dda=== The Brahmi letter Dda, Dda, is probably derived from the altered Aramaic Dalet 13px, and is thus related to the modern Latin D and Greek Delta. Several identifiable styles of writing the Brahmi Dda can be found, most associated with a specific set of inscriptions from an artifact or diverse records from an historic period.Evolutionary chart, Journal of the Asiatic Society of Bengal Vol 7, 1838 As the earliest and most geometric style of Brahmi, the letters found on the Edicts of Ashoka and other records from around that time are normally the reference form for Brahmi letters, with vowel marks not attested until later forms of Brahmi back-formed to match the geometric writing style. {|class="wikitable" |+Brahmi Dda historic forms |- !Ashoka (3rd-1st c. BCE) !! Girnar (~150 BCE) !! Kushana (~150-250 CE) !! Gujarat (~250 CE) !! Gupta (~350 CE) |- | 37px || 37px || 37px || 37px || 37px |} ===Tocharian Dda=== The Tocharian letter Dda is derived from the Brahmi Dda, but does not have an alternate Fremdzeichen form. {|class="wikitable" |+Tocharian Dda with vowel marks |- ! Dda !! Ddā !! Ddi !! Ddī !! Ddu !! Ddū !! Ddr !! Ddr̄ !! Dde !! Ddai !! Ddo !! Ddau !! Ddä |- | 37px || 37px || 37px || 37px || 37px || 37px || || || 37px || 37px || 37px || 37px || 37px |} ===Kharoṣṭhī Dda=== The Kharoṣṭhī letter Dda is generally accepted as being derived from the altered Aramaic Dalet 13px, and is thus related to D and Delta, in addition to the Brahmi Dda. ==Devanagari Ḍa== Ḍa (ड) is a consonant of the Devanagari abugida. It ultimately arose from the Brahmi letter ka, after having gone through the Gupta letter 13px. Letters that derive from it are the Gujarati letter ડ, and the Modi letter 𑘚. ===Devanagari-using Languages=== In all languages, ड is pronounced as or when appropriate. Like all Indic scripts, Devanagari uses vowel marks attached to the base consonant to override the inherent /ə/ vowel: {|class="wikitable" |+ Devanagari ड with vowel marks |- ! Ḍa !! Ḍā !! Ḍi !! Ḍī !! Ḍu !! Ḍū !! Ḍr !! Ḍr̄ !! Ḍl !! Ḍl̄ !! Ḍe !! Ḍai !! Ḍo !! Ḍau !! Ḍ |-style="font-size: 150%;" |ड |डा |डि |डी |डु |डू |डृ |डॄ |डॢ |डॣ |डे |डै |डो |डौ |ड् |} ===Conjuncts with ड=== Devanagari exhibits conjunct ligatures, as is common in Indic scripts. In modern Devanagari texts, most conjuncts are formed by reducing the letter shape to fit tightly to the following letter, usually by dropping a character's vertical stem, sometimes referred to as a "half form". Some conjunct clusters are always represented by a true ligature, instead of a shape that can be broken into constituent independent letters. Vertically stacked conjuncts are ubiquitous in older texts, while only a few are still used routinely in modern Devanagari texts. Ḍa however, does not have a vertical stem to drop for making a half form, and either forms a stacked conjunct/ligature, or uses its full form with Virama. The use of ligatures and vertical conjuncts may vary across languages using the Devanagari script, with Marathi in particular preferring the use of half forms where texts in other languages would show ligatures and vertical stacks. ====Ligature conjuncts of ड==== True ligatures are quite rare in Indic scripts. The most common ligated conjuncts in Devanagari are in the form of a slight mutation to fit in context or as a consistent variant form appended to the adjacent characters. Those variants include Na and the Repha and Rakar forms of Ra. Nepali and Marathi texts use the "eyelash" Ra half form Ra for an initial "R" instead of repha. * र্ (r) + ड (ḍa) gives us the ligature rḍa: 100px * ड্ (ḍ) + र (ra) gives us the ligature ḍra: 100px * ड্ (ḍ) + य (ya) gives us the ligature ḍya: 100px ====Stacked conjuncts of ड==== Vertically stacked ligatures are the most common conjunct forms found in Devanagari text. Although the constituent characters may need to be stretched and moved slightly in order to stack neatly, stacked conjuncts can be broken down into recognizable base letters, or a letter and an otherwise standard ligature. * ब্ (b) + ड (ḍa) gives us the ligature bḍa: 100px * भ্ (bʰ) + ड (ḍa) gives us the ligature bʰḍa: 100px * च্ (c) + ड (ḍa) gives us the ligature cḍa: 100px * छ্ (cʰ) + ड (ḍa) gives us the ligature cʰḍa: 100px * ड্ (ḍ) + ब (ba) gives us the ligature ḍba: 100px * ड্ (ḍ) + भ (bʰa) gives us the ligature ḍbʰa: 100px * ड্ (ḍ) + च (ca) gives us the ligature ḍca: 100px * ड্ (ḍ) + छ (cʰa) gives us the ligature ḍcʰa: 100px * ड্ (ḍ) + द (da) gives us the ligature ḍda: 100px * द্ (d) + ड (ḍa) gives us the ligature dḍa: 100px * ड্ (ḍ) + ड (ḍa) gives us the ligature ḍḍa: 100px * ड্ (ḍ) + ढ (ḍʱa) gives us the ligature ḍḍʱa: 100px * ड্ (ḍ) + ध (dʱa) gives us the ligature ḍdʱa: 100px * ड্ (ḍ) + ग (ga) gives us the ligature ḍga: 100px * ड্ (ḍ) + घ (ɡʱa) gives us the ligature ḍɡʱa: 100px * ड্ (ḍ) + ह (ha) gives us the ligature ḍha: 100px * ढ্ (ḍʱ) + ड (ḍa) gives us the ligature ḍʱḍa: 100px * ड্ (ḍ) + ज (ja) gives us the ligature ḍja: 100px * ड্ (ḍ) + झ (jʰa) gives us the ligature ḍjʰa: 100px * ड্ (ḍ) + ज্ (j) + ञ (ña) gives us the ligature ḍjña: 100px * ड্ (ḍ) + क (ka) gives us the ligature ḍka: 100px * ड্ (ḍ) + ख (kʰa) gives us the ligature ḍkʰa: 100px * ड্ (ḍ) + क্ (k) + ष (ṣa) gives us the ligature ḍkṣa: 100px * ड্ (ḍ) + ल (la) gives us the ligature ḍla: 100px * ड্ (ḍ) + ळ (ḷa) gives us the ligature ḍḷa: 100px * ड্ (ḍ) + म (ma) gives us the ligature ḍma: 100px * ड্ (ḍ) + न (na) gives us the ligature ḍna: 100px * ड্ (ḍ) + ङ (ŋa) gives us the ligature ḍŋa: 100px * ड্ (ḍ) + ण (ṇa) gives us the ligature ḍṇa: 100px * ड্ (ḍ) + ञ (ña) gives us the ligature ḍña: 100px * ड্ (ḍ) + प (pa) gives us the ligature ḍpa: 100px * ड্ (ḍ) + फ (pʰa) gives us the ligature ḍpʰa: 100px * ड্ (ḍ) + स (sa) gives us the ligature ḍsa: 100px * ड্ (ḍ) + श (ʃa) gives us the ligature ḍʃa: 100px * ड্ (ḍ) + ष (ṣa) gives us the ligature ḍṣa: 100px * ड্ (ḍ) + त (ta) gives us the ligature ḍta: 100px * ड্ (ḍ) + थ (tʰa) gives us the ligature ḍtʰa: 100px * ड্ (ḍ) + ट (ṭa) gives us the ligature ḍṭa: 100px * ड্ (ḍ) + ठ (ṭʰa) gives us the ligature ḍṭʰa: 100px * ड্ (ḍ) + व (va) gives us the ligature ḍva: 100px * ध্ (dʱ) + ड (ḍa) gives us the ligature dʱḍa: 100px * घ্ (ɡʱ) + ड (ḍa) gives us the ligature ɡʱḍa: 100px * ज্ (j) + ड (ḍa) gives us the ligature jḍa: 100px * झ্ (jʰ) + ड (ḍa) gives us the ligature jʰḍa: 100px * क্ (k) + ड (ḍa) gives us the ligature kḍa: 100px * ख্ (kʰ) + ड (ḍa) gives us the ligature kʰḍa: 100px * ळ্ (ḷ) + ड (ḍa) gives us the ligature ḷḍa: 100px * म্ (m) + ड (ḍa) gives us the ligature mḍa: 100px * ङ্ (ŋ) + ड (ḍa) gives us the ligature ŋḍa: 100px * प্ (p) + ड (ḍa) gives us the ligature pḍa: 100px * फ্ (pʰ) + ड (ḍa) gives us the ligature pʰḍa: 100px * ष্ (ṣ) + ड (ḍa) gives us the ligature ṣḍa: 100px * थ্ (tʰ) + ड (ḍa) gives us the ligature tʰḍa: 100px * ट্ (ṭ) + ड (ḍa) gives us the ligature ṭḍa: 100px * ठ্ (ṭʰ) + ड (ḍa) gives us the ligature ṭʰḍa: 100px * व্ (v) + ड (ḍa) gives us the ligature vḍa: 100px * य্ (y) + ड (ḍa) gives us the ligature yḍa: 100px ==Bengali Dda== The Bengali script ড is derived from the Siddhaṃ 13px, and is marked by a similar horizontal head line, but less geometric shape, than its Devanagari counterpart, ड. The inherent vowel of Bengali consonant letters is /ɔ/, so the bare letter ড will sometimes be transliterated as "ddo" instead of "dda". Adding okar, the "o" vowel mark, gives a reading of /d̳o/. Like all Indic consonants, ড can be modified by marks to indicate another (or no) vowel than its inherent "a". {|class="wikitable" |+ Bengali ড with vowel marks |- ! dda !! ddā !! ddi !! ddī !! ddu !! ddū !! ddr !! ddr̄ !! dde !! ddai !! ddo !! ddau !! dd |-style="font-size: 150%;" |ড |ডা |ডি |ডী |ডু |ডূ |ডৃ |ডৄ |ডে |ডৈ |ডো |ডৌ |ড্ |} ===ড in Bengali-using languages=== ড is used as a basic consonant character in all of the major Bengali script orthographies, including Bengali and Assamese. ===Conjuncts with ড=== Bengali ড exhibits conjunct ligatures, as is common in Indic scripts, with a tendency towards stacked ligatures. * ড্ (ḍ) + ড (ḍa) gives us the ligature ḍḍa: 100px * ড্ (ḍ) + র (ra) gives us the ligature ḍra, with the ra phala suffix: 100px * ড্ (ḍ) + ব (va) gives us the ligature ḍva, with the va phala suffix: 100px * ড্ (ḍ) + য (ya) gives us the ligature ḍya, with the ya phala suffix: 100px * ল্ (l) + ড (ḍa) gives us the ligature lḍa: 100px * ন্ (n) + ড (ḍa) gives us the ligature nḍa: 100px * ন্ (n) + ড্ (ḍ) + র (ra) gives us the ligature nḍra, with the ra phala suffix: 100px * ণ্ (ṇ) + ড (ḍa) gives us the ligature ṇḍa: 100px * ণ্ (ṇ) + ড্ (ḍ) + র (ra) gives us the ligature ṇḍra, with the ra phala suffix: 100px * ণ্ (ṇ) + ড্ (ḍ) + য (ya) gives us the ligature ṇḍya, with the ya phala suffix: 100px * র্ (r) + ড (ḍa) gives us the ligature rḍa, with the repha prefix: 100px ==Javanese Dda== ==References== Category:Indic letters
title: Ḍa (Indic)
